reviews: I've owned several Fenix lights before and have always been a fan of their products. This light is my first one to use something other than a AA or AAA battery. I was a bit skeptical of the 18650 battery at first but after a little research I found it to probably be the best form factor for this type of light. High output, long life and rechargeable. The light itself is very well made, sturdy and fit and finish is excellent. The light feels solid in your hand and isn't too heavy. The tailcap switch is easy to use for both momentary and on/off operation. The function or dimmer button is also easy to use to cycle through the different modes and brightness levels. I've since made this flashlight part of my primary EDC. I purchased several 18650 batteries and a charger to keep spares at home, in my truck and EDC bag. You can use two CR123A's if you don't have an 18650.

reviews:
It is hard to describe the quality of these little guys. From the moment you pick it up, you have the feeling of quality. Details are finely crafted, everywhere you look.

And turning this unit on, is truly spectacular. The amount of light that comes out defies logic! How can such a small light produce such a bright light? You really have to experience it!

I keep one in the truck and one on my night stand. I find that I keep the "memory" of the unit at a medium level. That way, when it comes on, you have a "normal" flashlight level of lighting. With just the push of a button, you can increase that to an amazing level, but for the most part, I don't need that level.

These little guys really are the best flashlights I have ever owned. Yeah, they are not cheap. I can't argue that. But as with many things in life, you get what you pay for. In this case, you get a flashlight that will probably outlast you and perform without fail, every single time.

reviews:
So first of all, this is my second PD35 so my review is of both, and I want to tell you how I came to have two. My original PD35 (right side in the picture) was purchased locally about 6 years ago, I soon after purchased 2 Fenix brand 3400mAh batteries with a charger and have literally never had an issue with the flashlight or batteries since.
Last year few weeks before Christmas we got our first snowfall and I decided to go for a drive in it, upon returning home I noticed that my PD35 was missing (it was clipped to my belt with the pocket clip because the sheath had given out, more on that later).
I have had this flashlight with me basically every day of my life for 6 years now, so I immediately ordered a replacement.
Fast forward about 2 months and multiple snow storms later, the snow and ice had taken a bit of a cutting and as I am getting into my car one day I noticed something in the driveway embedded in the ice (see second picture, with flashlight shaped print in ice), lo and behold, it's my original PD35! I pry it out of the ice, click the button, and it's very dim, but it turned on! One charged battery later and it is working just as good as the day I bought it.
I am a avid mountain biker, hiker and skier, as well as an automotive service technician for the last 1.5 years. I have used this flashlight in the worst possible conditions, gotten it covered in many different chemicals and oils, I even used it inside the sand-blasting cabinet at work when the built in light gave out! And it has NEVER LET ME DOWN.
If you buy a Fenix PD35 you will never need another flashlight again so long as you don't lose it, end of story.

As previously mentioned the ONLY issue I have ever had is not with the flashlight itself, but the included sheath, both of the sheaths that came with my flashlights have fallen apart after several months of (hard) use, I wouldn't subtract a star for this as the flashlight is 150% deserving of a 5 star rating, but it would be nice to have a sheath that matched the quality of the light.

reviews: But the batteries are not easy to find and too expensive. And the controls are simply dumb. The on / off is on the end and the brightness control is a small button on the barrel that has you fumbling with both hands to find it. An amazingly poor design. Not surprising, it gets hot after a couple minutes on high. The beam is not adjustable so the huge output of light, and it is huge, is spread on a fairly wide area. This means the distance the brightness reaches is limited. We have a Maglite that is only 300 lumens but the beam can be focused and the reach out is much better. I do not recommend this model.

review_title: Don't hesitate just buy this light now!
reviews:
I am a HUGE flashlight guy. And I love this light and this brand! This is my 6th Fenix brand light. I am a customer for life. The PD35 TAC is a great light for EDC and tactical use. The 1000 Lumen setting is extremely bright. I was able to light up a hillside over 200 yards out. It feels great in the hand. Easy to cycle through settings. I keep my light on 500 lumens at work and during the day and 1000 lumen tactical setting at night and on weekends. Be careful what you shine the light at as it is so bright that it reflects off some surfaces easily and you can temporarily blind yourself. The quality of this light is amazing as always with Fenix. I highly recommend this light to everyone looking to carry a flashlight for any reason. With lumen settings of 8, 60, 200, 500 and 1000 as well as 1000 lumen strobe there is a setting for every senario.
You will not be disappointed with this light. I can not recommend this light or brand enough.
If you get this light I also suggest getting one ore two 18650 rechargeable batteries. If you are like me and use 1000 lumen setting alot you will burn through a lot of CR123 batteries.

Also the pocket clip is really good quality and is by far the best clip I have had on any light including previous Fenix lights. It is really strong and stiff. You do not need to worry about losing your light.

reviews: I bought mine from fenix themselves because at the time the only sellers of them on amazon were 3rd party and fenix themselves said they were all china counterfeiters. I would buy from amazon themselves though. I wanna say to the fool who gave it a negative review because he had no idea how to work it and never bothered to read the instructions judging by his stupid comments that before you give it a negative review learn how to use the bloody item 1st! Therefore you don’t sound stupid. Ok this light does change to different lumin power strengths. The tail button is for off and on and the side button changes the modes. The reason is because a lot of lights change modes(powers/strobe) by the rear button and often switch to the main set mode by the factory. Now if you’re a cop you don’t want your flashlight to always start on eco. So the fenix system lets you put it in the power mode you want and then it’ll always be ready to go when you press the tail button. It works better than the other systems in my opinion. Now to anyone not sure about the 18650 batteries I can tell you that it’s far far superior to AA batteries. That being said it’s just like regular batteries, there’s great ones and crappy ones. Panasonic makes the best of them by far. Independent tests prove it. You can get a good Panasonic 18650 battery here on amazon. The more powerful the brighter your flashlight will be for longer. Obviously it won’t surpass the manufacturers output but it will get to that full output and stay at that far longer. For example using my light on eco mode which is I think 40 lumens I only charged my battery once in 6 months and others I’ve heard went 9 months. Remember it’s all going to matter how often & how long you use it for each use. I used mine everyday but only for minutes each time. Still 6 months is a long time. At the full 1000 lumens it lasts a decent amount of time. It’ll automatically switch down if it gets too hot. This is also a true 1000 lumens. Do not believe all those lights claiming 2500-18000 lumens because it’s a lie. A real 2500 lumens flashlight will cost at least $200 and a 4000 lumens light will be $350 or more. They also can start fires at those lumens if they didn’t switch down. There’s some made to stay at 2500 lumens so that you can use your flashlight to start a fire. Like for camping. So normal lights won’t stay at a high lumens level for long because of the high heat and fire risk. I saw a china manufacturer and seller on amazon selling a headlamp claiming it had 18000 lumens, hilarious! 1st the higher the lumens the more powerful battery power you need. Also 18000 lumens would severely burn your head. So do your research and don’t buy into all those fraudulent claims about super high lumens. Oh I should point out that there’s no safe cheap china made batteries that are high milliamps. The most common quality 18650 power is 2600-3500 mAh. Again do your research but the batteries most experts & even flashlight manufacturers use are Panasonic, Fenix, Nitecore, & Olight. Everything I’ve read & from my own experiences always keeps me going back to Panasonic. Again don’t just accept my opinion but do your own research. The better you get the more you’ll get out of it. My fenix flashlight is going strong after 6 years and that’s real world use. I’ve had to get a couple of batteries over that time but they all will eventually start to decrease in power. The best last the longest though & are the most reliable and safe for that matter. Bar a long long way. I’ve paid $35 for the battery but it was strong for over 2 years. I had cheap backups where I got 4 batteries for that price and they all together didn’t last a year! I was also scared charging them because of all the stories of cheap batteries exploding. It’s not worth going cheap. Save if you have to because remember pay a more once or pay less many times. It is my opinion but from my own experience I feel comfortable recommending this fenix pd35 tac flashlight to all. 6yrs and still going strong says a lot to me. By the way be careful using the strobe light because it’s 1000 lumens and it hurts even with your eyelids closed. The user can also go into a seizure from the strobe mode so be careful if you have epilepsy.

reviews:
This came as a replacement to the PD30 I used to own, which unfortunately, it seems, might have burned out after I inserted the batteries the wrong way around. The PD35 has circuit protection features to prevent that. The button on the side is very useful to switch modes. The PD35 also runs much cooler than the previous model, which after a couple of minutes could grill your fingers. It has been dropped a few times, and it has resisted so far. The batteries last an eternity, but I do recommend using non-rechargeables if you don't have a spare pair of rechargeables all the time. They seem to last at three times as much, so if you're out and about with no access to your second pair or rechargeables, go for regular ones.
When it's running on full charge, the beam can reach easily 40 yards on the highest setting. Up close, if you point it to a wall less than 3 meters away, it will hurt your eyes just by looking at the wall!

#401 in Handheld Flashlights

reviews:
Ich hatte seit 2014 die TN12 der Marke Thrunite in verschiedenen Versionen, nun kam es zum zweiten Mal zu einem Defekt, weshalb ich mich von Thrunite abgewandt habe.

Als Konkurrenz zur Thrunite kam für mich die Fenix PD35TAC und die Klarus XT11GT in Frage. Letztlich habe ich mich aus zwei Gründen für die Fenix PD35TAC entschieden 1. Der Preis und 2. Der taktische Modus.

Ich werde nun die einzelnen Eigenschaften der Fenix PD35TAC bewerten und mit der Thrunite TN12 2016 vergleichen.

Helligkeit:
Die Helligkeit nach Ansi-Standard wird bei der Fenix mit 1000 Lumen angegeben. Die Thrunite hingegen soll sogar 1100 Lumen erreichen. Ich persönlich konnte auch beim direkten Vergleich keine Unterschiede feststellen. Ich bin auch nach Jahren immer noch begeistert, wie viel Licht aus einer kleinen Taschenlampe kommen kann.
Unentschieden zwischen Fenix und Thrunite (beide 5 von 5)

Bedienung:
Im normalen Modus funktioniert die Fenix fast gleich wie die Thrunite. Anschalten mit dem großen Knopf am hinteren Ende der Taschenlampe, danach kann mit dem kleinen Knopf an der Vorderseite durch die verschiedenen Modi geschaltet werden. Fünf verschiedene Helligkeitsstufen und der Strobo Modus, hier wird in dem Modus in dem man ausgeschaltet hat auch wieder angefangen. Leider habe ich bei der Thrunite immer wieder am hellsten Modus vorbeigeschaltet, da ich teilweise nicht sicher war wann dieser erreicht ist.
Jetzt zum Hauptunterschied zwischen Fenix und Thrunite. Der taktische Modus, den nur die Fenix beherrscht. Diesen kann man durch 3-sekündiges halten des kleinen Knopfes am Kopfende der Taschenlampe aktivieren. Im taktischen Modus ist ausschließlich der große Knopf mit einer Funktion belegt.
Der Knopf kann auch "halb" gedrückt werden. Damit kann man im taktischen Modus zwischen drei Modi wählen, 1. Volle Helligkeit 2. Strobo 3. Ca. 50% Helligkeit.
Das Gute ist, sobald der große Knopf komplett gedrückt wird schält die Lampe Anfangs immer in den hellsten Modus.
Fenix schlägt Thrunite (Fenix 5 von 5, Thrunite 4 von 5)

Verarbeitung:
Beide Taschenlampen sind sehr gut verarbeitet und bestehen fast komplett aus Metall. Der einzige Unterschied ist der kleine Knopf an der Vorderseite der Lampe. Bei Fenix besteht der Knopf aus Metall, steht aber nicht sehr weit aus dem Gehäuse heraus, sodass er nicht so einfach gefunden werden kann. Bei Thrunite steht er weiter hervor, besteht aber aus Kunststoff. Des weiteren kann der Knopf bei Thrunite versehentlich gedrückt werden. Im taktischen Modus, den ich benutze ist der Knopf sowieso ohne Funktion, weshalb mir das Finden des Knopfs nicht so wichtig ist.
Fenix schlägt Thrunite (Fenix 5 von 5, Thrunite 4 von 5)

Zuverlässigkeit:
Das war für mich der aller wichtigste Punkt. Ich muss mich zu 100% auf meine Taschenlampe verlassen können. Das war bei meiner Thrunite nicht gegeben, sie hatte ab und an einen Fehler. Nachdem der Knopf losgelassen wurde ging die Lampe wieder aus. Dies geschah in ca. 10-15% der Fällen. Bei der Fenix ist das noch nie passiert. Den zweiten Kritikpunkt habe ich bereits unter "Bedienung" angesprochen. Bei der Thrunite muss immer wieder durch alle Modi geschaltet werden bis man den hellsten erreicht.
Fenix schlägt Thrunite (Fenix 5 von 5, Thrunite 3 von 5)

Fazit:
Helligkeit: Fenix 5 von 5 // Thrunite 5 von 5
Bedienung: Fenix 5 von 5 // Thrunite 4 von 5
Verarbeitung: Fenix 5 von 5 // Thrunite 4 von 5
Zuverlässigkeit: Fenix 5 von 5 // Thrunite 3 von 5

Fenix 20 von 20
Thrunite 16 von 20

Hier muss aber bedacht werden, dass die Fenix 15€ mehr kostet als die Thrunite.

Ich persönlich würde jedem die Fenix empfehlen. Wer aber nicht bereit ist die extra 15€ zu investieren, der ist auch mit der Thrunite gut bedient, zumindest solange diese 100% funktionsfähig ist.

reviews:
La lampe torche ne fonctionne déjà plus après +- 6 mois d'utilisations dans le cadre professionnel.
J’ai donc pris contact avec le fabriquant qui n’a rien voulu savoir. Message en gras, rouge et de grande taille pour préciser qu’AUCUNE GARANTIE n’est appliquée si le produit n’est pas commandé sur leur propre site. Le problème c’est que deux sites différents existent pour le territoire français et que les deux n’ont pas fière allure, pour ne pas dire qu’ils ont l’air factice. De plus l’adresse postale utilisée dans les deux sites mènent à un cul de sac ou une rue étrange, non adaptée à une société de cette envergure.

Le mail en lui-même est écrit de manière agressive, et condescendante, et quelques fautes d’orthographe sont disséminées par-ci par-là. Pas très malin quand on veut jouer au plus compétant dans une histoire comme celle-ci.
Bref, passez votre chemin, vous en serez déçu sur le long terme.

reviews:
Die Taschenlampe ist super hell und ist mehr als ausreichend für fast alle Situationen.
Auf maximaler Stufe sogar oft zu hell da man im Dunkeln sofort jemand blendet oder man ist selbst geblendet wenn man einen reflektierenden oder weisen Gegenstand anleuchtet. Zusäzlich ist sie klein genug dass man sie überall mit hinnehmen kann.

Das Gewicht, die Verarbeitung und die Optik machen alle einen sehr guten Eindruck und es ist auch jetzt nach einem Jahr noch alles super.

Ein Punkt der mich jedoch immer wieder stört ist die "kurze" Laufzeit auf maximaler Stufe und dass sie dann langsam immer dunkler wird.
Da ich das aber nicht mit einer anderen so hellen Taschenlampe vergleichen kann und es evtl. nicht besser machbar ist, gebe ich hier keinen Punkt Abzug.

Ein kleiner Tipp wäre ggf. noch einen Diffusor dazu zu kaufen, dann kann man sehr schön größere Flächen ausleuchten und man Blendet deutlich weniger.
product_name: Fenix Flashlights FX-PD35TAC Flashlight, 1000 Lumen, Black
rank:
#44,763 in Tools & Home Improvement (See Top 100 in Tools & Home Improvement)
#401 in Handheld Flashlights

reviews:
Auf Grund guter Testberichte im Netz habe ich mir die FENIX, PD35 TAC gekauft!

Ich habe sie mit der chinesischen No-Name Leynatic LED-Taschenlampe verglichen!

Als die Fenix ankam war ich ziemlich enttäuscht, ich dachte es wären Batterien enthalten, komischerweise war bei manchen Nutzern welche dabei und bei anderen nicht! Aktueller Stand es sind leider keine Batterien enthalten, da steht auch kein Hinweis in der Beschreibung!

Mit der Bedienung kann ich mich nicht wirklich anfreunden! Am Ende befindet sich der Ein und Ausschaltknopf! Möchte man die Beleuchtungsstärke wechseln geht dafür nur der zweite Knopf vorne im Bereich Lampenkopf! Die Strobofunktion lässt sich nur im eingeschalteten Zustand aktivieren! In dem man den vorderen Knopf zweimal schnell drückt! Da ich die Taschenlampe gerne kopfüber halte, kann ich die Stobofunktion nicht mit dem kleinen Finger aktivieren bzw. der Lichtstärken wechsel funktioniert so nur schwer!

Die Taschenlampe lässt auch nicht als Notfalllampe auf den Tisch stellen, da der Einschaltknopf zu weit heraussteht!

Die Fenix kostet 59,90€ plus Fenix 468659 3500mAh 3,6V - 3,7V Li-Ionen Akku PCB 21€ plus Fenix ARE-C1 Ladegerät 32,95€, dass sind um die 115€! Das ist wirklich teuer!

Ich habe sie mit der chinesischen No-Name Leynatic LED-Taschenlampe verglichen die 19,99€ kostet und nur 800 Lumen hat! Komischerweise hält die No-Name Taschenlampe mit 800 Lumen in Sachen Leuchtkraft mit der Fenix mit 1000 Lumen mit ! Wie geht den dass? Der Zentrale Lichtpunkt ist tatsächlich bei beiden Taschenlampe identisch!

Für mich ist dass wirklich enttäuschend, der erste Eindruck ist nicht positiv! Gut finde ich nur, dass sie schön handlich ist, gut verarbeitet wirkt, Spritzwassergeschützt ist, der Akku entnehmbar ist und eine kleine Tragetasche dabei ist!

Aber in meinen Augen stimmt hier die Preis-Leistung nicht!

Auf dem Bild sieht man links die No-Name und rechts die Fenix!

Update 15.10.2018:

Ich werte die Taschenlampe um einen Stern auf! Sie ist doch deutlich heller als die No-Name! Bei der Fenix konnte sich die Turbo-Stufe nicht einschalten lassen, der Grund war dass die Batterie zu schwach war!

reviews:
Questo prodotto è il top in circolazione per quanto riguarda le mini torce, sia sotto il profilo del prezzo che delle prestazioni.
Nella mia vita ho provato due Surefire ad incandescenza, la Maglite XL200, e posso dire che la Fenix PD35 è la migliore tra i cataloghi di Maglite, Surefire e Fenix, perché coniuga una grande autonomia, la possiblità di usare batteria al litio ricaricabili e dal basso costo, ed ha una potenza pazzesca: anche il riflesso su una superficie bianca acceca gli occhi. L'unica cosa che gli manca è la possibilità di regolare la frequenza di lampeggiamento in modalità stroboscopica, ma per il resto è perfetta.
La dotazione di accessori è altresì completa: o-ring di sostituzione, laccetti, e custodia

reviews:
Ich habe mir die PD35 TAC zugelegt um auf Wanderungen und bei Zeltlagern das Handy beziehungsweise die Fahrradlampe daheim lassen zu können.

Deshalb stellte ich mir folgende Anforderungen an das Produkt:
- Leichtes Gewicht, hohe Batterielaufzeit (bei 7-tägigen Zeltlagern wichtig!)
- Sowohl eine weite, sehr helle Ausstrahlung als auch ein nahes "Nachtlicht". Die weite Ausstrahlung soll insbesondere während nächtlicher Wanderungen der Orientierung dienen. Hingegen soll das Nachtlicht oder im Dixi-Klo eingesetzt werden ;-) Teilweise auch, um nahflächig Hindernisse zu erkennen oder um die Karte zu lesen.
- Ein Strobo-Effekt könnte die Abwehr krimineller Menschen erleichtern.. Oder die Abwehr von Tieren.

Obwohl die Wanderung erst in etwa einer Woche beginnt, habe ich gestern bereits schon einmal das Produkt getestet. Der Strobo-Effekt tut schon hinter der Taschenlampe im Kopf weh und sowohl das Nachtlicht ist ausreichend dunkel sowie auch das Fernlicht leuchtet bei über 200m Abstand die Gebäude aus.

Die Verarbeitung wirkt auch hochwertig und das Gewicht der Taschenlampe fällt in der Hosentasche gar nicht auf.

Ergänzend habe ich mir von der Firma Base Tech ein Ladegerät für die 18650er Akkus gekauft, um diese im Notfall an meiner Powerbank zu laden.
product_name: Fenix Flashlights FX-PD35TAC Flashlight, 1000 Lumen, Black
rank:
#44,763 in Tools & Home Improvement (See Top 100 in Tools & Home Improvement)
#401 in Handheld Flashlights

review_title: Presque neuve : panne vissage après 10 mois.
reviews:
Fenix PD35 TAC achat fin février 2019. Très peu utilisée, comme neuve. Très bien jusqu'à la panne fin décembre 2019.
Changement de batterie après recharge.
Ne fonctionne plus depuis.
Essai avec d'autres batteries chargées mais problème subsiste.
Problème alors que la lampe est comme neuve presque pas utilisée à l'extérieur.
Fabricant injoignable (voir avis très pertinent sur ce sujet ici même).
Impossible de voir la duree de garantie Amazon : aucune mension, retour plus proposé.
Après recherche sur internet je constate que le problème est connu pour différentes lampes torche Fenix, à savoir un fonctionnement heratique en début de vissage puis arrêt de la lampe en cours et fin de vissage.
Voir ma photo avec éclairage sur le début de vissage et la lampe qui fonctionne ainsi.
Lampe inutilisable. 66 euros perdus.
Je vais essayer le SAV Amazon.
Dommage car lampe qualitative par ailleurs.

review_title: FENIX PD35TAC - tolle Allrooundlampe ohne Spielereien
reviews:
Ich habe zum Vergleich die FD41 und die FD30 von Fenix bestellt:
Die PD35TAC ist eine tolle Allround-Lampe ohne viele Spielerein mit genialem Fernlicht. Das Nahlicht besteht einen einem hellen Punkt mit einem erkennbar dunklerem Hof.
Die FD30 besticht in der Flutlichteinstellung durch eine recht gleichmäßige Ausleuchtung des Nahbereiches und macht dabei genug Licht, um das Gelände bis zu 20m gut auszuleuchten. Im Fernlicht leuchtet die FD30 zwar genau so weit wie die PD35TAC, jedoch nur einen vergleichsweise kleinen Bereich aus - was mir persönlich nicht so gut gefallen hat.
Bei der FD41 muss man lichttechnisch keine Kompromisse machen. Das Flutlicht ist perfekt und kräftig ausgeleuchtet (noch besser als bei der FD30) und im Fernlicht steht sie der PD35TAC keineswegs nach. Einzig bei Größe und Gewicht muss man hier den Kompromiss eingehen. Die FD41 ist am Kopf spürbar größer und auch etwas schwerer. Wenn man sie jedoch im mitgelieferten Holster trägt, spielt das keine Rolle mehr.

reviews: Ich bin sehr zufrieden mit dieser Taschenlampe. Ich habe sie gekauft, um auf unserem Freizeitgrundstück nachts große Flächen ausleuchten zu können. Stufe 3 ist für den normalen Gebrauch ausreichend. Auf höchster Stufe gleicht das Ding einem LED Autoscheinwerfer.

review_title: Gute Lampe aber es gibt günstigere Alternativen mit vergleichbarer Qualität
reviews: Ich habe zwei ganz ähnliche Lampen. Diese hier von Fenix ist über jeden oder fast jeden Zweifel erhaben. Dann hab ich mir als erklärter LED Fan auch noch ein ganz ähnliches Modell geholt von TruNight oder so ähnlich. Sie ist genau so hell, fast noch einen Tuck heller. Was mir aber definitiv besser gefällt bei der deutlich günstigeren Lampe, die ähnlich gut verarbeitet scheint, ist der besser fühlbare seitliche Schalter. Er steht etwas mehr raus aus dem Lampenkörper als bei der Fenix. Fazit: Die Fenix ist ihr Geld sicher wert aber dann ist die andere topgünstig.

review_title: Prodotto professionale e di qualità. La marca è per questo una garanzia indiscussa.
reviews:
Questa marca non delude mai. Fascio di luce intenso e potente, durata della carica più che soddisfacente. Qualità e robustezza dei materiali assolutamente percettibili.
Il prezzo è assolutamente giustificato dalle qualità del prodotto.
Facile altresì l’utilizzo, con il pulsante dedicato all’intensità del fascio di luce da utilizzare in cinque varianti. La torcia pesa poco ed è maneggevole pur senza risultare scivolosa.
Io la uso per lavoro, nulla a che vedere con le torce “cinesi” da 10 euro.

reviews: Hace tiempo compré una linterna fenix para mi bicicleta y es una de las mejores compras de mi vida; ellos me llevó a escoger fenix sobre cualquier otra linterna. En esta ocasión pedí la PD35 y llegó sin funcionar, compré pilas recargables y pilas normales, ya que pensé que eran las pilas las que no funcionaban, traté de nuevo y no prendió pero Amazon me mandó inmediatamente otra linterna y aceptó mi devolución. Cuando llegó la nueva la probé, prendía así que la guardé. Acabo de ir a acampar y la linterna no sirve, prende y se apaga en unos segundos, es una verdadera decepción ya que ya se cerró mi ventana de devolución, No sé se este modelo salió defectuoso pero 2 linternas del mismo modelo que no sirven debe decirnos algo...

#401 in Handheld Flashlights

reviews:
Although I'm not a fully-blown flashlight fan, I do have a few and like a nice bright torch. I was a little apprehensive of spending a reasonable amount of money on a torch, however I was not disappointed.

For such a small torch, the output is staggering. I've read independent reviews online which do confirm the full 1000 lumens (or more) are produced, and it certainly seems that way. There are 5 brightness settings, with the front silver button indexing through and the back button allowing momentary or constant on lighting. You can also toggle to 'tactical' mode by holding down the silver button, which triggers the strobe feature at 1000 lumens. (Certainly enough to dazzle a would-be assailant at night, or even during the day, or to signal for help). I've tried the torch in a pitch black room and at full output, it's brighter than if every light were switched on. The beam itself cannot be adjusted or focused, but this is not really needed, as the light output is well focused (a wide, slightly dimmer outer beam, with a very bright central beam). The only downside is that the 1000 lumen brightness level will quickly eat up the batteries in only an hour, but this is not due to the torch, just the nature of the LED and on the lowest brightness level (10 lumens), the torch will last 140 hours.

The torch is nicely made from matte black anodised aluminium, with a small heatsink just behind the front section, which is certainly required, as on setting 4 and 5, quite a lot of heat is produced and can even be felt in front of the torch (surprising, for an LED). The power is electronically regulated for each brightness level and automatically drops from level 5 down to 4 and 4 down to 3 after pre-set time limits, so as not to cook the bulb. (it's possible, though inadvisable, to override these but turning off and on again). The front face of the torch is smooth, but has indented scallops as glass breaking sections. (so probably a useful torch to keep in the car for emergencies). There is an octagonal anti-roll section where the silver mode select button is located.

Flashlight comes in a small box, with one set of disposable lithium batteries provided, as well as a pouch with belt loop, a clip for the light (as shown in main photo) and a lanyard. Spare O-rings and a spare rear button are also included.

Overall, very impressed.

reviews:
This is a beast of a torch. I bought this as a go-to (kinda EDC type thing though I don't carry it absolutely everywhere).

Build Quality
It's a nice carry, sits nicely in the pocket with its heavy duty clip.
The construction is solid, anodising is very hard and scratch / chip resistant.
The lens is clear, the antireflective and antiscratch coatings appear to be very good and uniform.
The beam pattern is nice and circular, with no hot spots. There is a faint cold spot in the centre but only really noticeable when looking at uniform structures. Not an issue as very subtle.
The peripheral spread of the beam is nice and uniform, no messy leakage of light.
The brightness is sufficient for visualising small objects up to around 30 metres away and larger structures can be illumited from around 50m or so.

Modes
The strobe function is great - it's a variable strobe so it's not a predictable pattern, this makes it better for things like self-defence though I have no real need for this function.

You'll either love or hate the 'tactical mode' that the flashlight is defaulted to when shipped. The end clicky switch bascially gives you High-Strobe-Med by default, to access the other modes you have to hold down the other switch on the side of the body. I like this function as the mode I use the most is high and to get to medium for more close-up work such as map reading / accessing dark nooks and crannies is easy (my only gripe is having to go past the strobe mode to get to it). I haven't really used the non-tactical modes (low, etc) but I can see how this would be good in a situation where you need low-level lighting for long periods of time.

Power
I use Panasonic NCR18650NB 3400mAh cells in this, also bought from Amazon (see link) Panasonic NCR18650B Li-Ion 3400 mAh Cell Protected Battery (Pack of 2)

The battery life is good, I haven't had to replace them through lack of power though I regularly cycle the batteries through and keep them 'alive'.

Other Applications
1000lumens is more than enough though I wouldn't use it for cycling - it's too narrow in the beam spread so I use my Exposure Six-pack 2000lumen for this though I carry this as well for backup. I made a nifty bike mount from an old cycle pump mount and some hook'n'loop and it's reasonable for a emergency cycling light.

You can't stand this on its end - the knurling on the cap prevents this. I think this is a missed application though I have managed to create a base from Sugru rubber compound to get around this.

review_title: Hervorragende Lampe für den täglichen Einsatz
reviews:
Diese Version der PD35 ist bereits die dritte Inkarnation der PD35 Reihe. Die Urversion von 2013 hatte eine maximale Lichtausgabe von 850 Lumen, die Version von 2014 "leistete" 960 Lumen. Die aktuelle PD35tac wird mit 1000 Lumen im Turbo-Modus angegeben.

Wie bei allen diesen vergleichsweise schmalen und leichten Lampen können die Maximalwerte nur wenige Minuten gehalten werden, bevor die eingebauten Schutzschaltungen in einen niedrigeren Modus umschaltet. Die PD35tac verfügt über 5 Leuchtstufen, die vom Hersteller so angegeben werden:
1000 Lumen, für 1 Stunde 10 Minuten, 500 Lumen (2h 55min), 200 Lumen (8h 30 min), 60 Lumen (29h 15 min), sowie 8 Lumen (140h). Neu ist bei der tac Version, dass diese normale oder Outdoor Modus genannte Einstellung über den Seitenschalter auf den "taktischen" Modus umgeschaltet werden kann. Danach lässt sich die Lampe nur noch über den hinteren Klick-Schalter steuern und erlaubt noch genau 3 Modi.

1000 Lumen, Strobo, 60 Lumen. Dies lässt sich bereits nach wenigen Augenblicken sehr gut steuern. Wem diese Bedienung missfällt, kann über längeres Drücken des Seitenschalters zurück in den Outdoor-Modus wechseln.

Da ich bereits die Version von 2013 besitze, konnte ich beide Lampen einem Vergleich unterziehen. Die Helligkeitsunterschiede sind minimal - der Sprung von 850 auf 1000 Lumen rechtfertigt eine Neuanschaffung sicher nicht.Der Beam der "alten" Version ist etwas ausgedehnter und minimal dunkler, dies sind aber wirklich nur Nuancen.

Für mich bleibt die Fenix PD35 Reihe weiterhin eine der besten Taschenlampen, wenn man Lichtleistung und das (geringe) Gewicht berücksichtigt. Natürlich sollte man einen 18650 Akku einsetzen, um das volle Potential auszuschöpfen. Wichtig: der Akku sollte einen flachen Plus-Pol haben und nicht zu dick sein. Gerade die Akkus mit eingebauten Panasonic Zellen sind häufig zu voluminös.

review_title: Brilliant torch, good price, great product
reviews:
Brilliant torch. Very very powerful and very good range. I've had a few LED lenser before and they are excellent but this is brighter. Would buy again.

The only thing I would change on this torch is have a beam you can focus like on most the LED lenser flashlights.

Size is perfect, very compact and feels robust. Very light weight and the clip on the side keeps it secure in a pocket.

review_title: Verdammt helle Lampe mit einer Designschwäche
reviews:
Noch vor gut zehn Jahren gab es keine LED-Lampe, die derat viel Leistung gehabt hätte - es gab SureFire und diese waren mit um die 200 EUR recht teuer und boten meist um die 110 Lumen.

Die Fenix mit ihren 1.000 Lumen ist im Vergleich dazu wirklich eine bestaunenswerte Weiterentwicklung!
Die PD35Tac ist wertig verarbeitet und hat kompakte Maße.
Das Umstellen in den "Tac" Modus mag man für gewöhnlich und bei ziviler Anwendung kaum benötigen, aber einen Stern ziehe ich ab, da der silberne Druckschalter zum Wechsel des Leuchtmodus im Dunkeln kaum zu sehen und nur sehr schwer zu erfühlen ist!
Fenix hätte sich hier etwas besser "fühl-" oder "greifbares" einfallen lassen können.
Ansonsten ist die Lampe ein echter Flak-Scheinwerfer für die Hosentasche mit gut abgestimmten Leuchtmodi.

review_title: Compatta e leggera, ma con una luce incredibile. La serie PD3x di Fenix non delude neanche questa volta!
reviews:
Utilizzo torce compatte della serie PD3x di Phenix da anni: prima una PD30 e poi una PD32, e mi sono sempre trovata benissimo. Sono compatte, leggere, ma molto molto potenti quanto a illuminazione.
Ovviamente quando serve, perché all'occorrenza la uso anche come torcia notturna per muovermi in casa al buio, quindi con intensità della luce al minimo, in modo da evitare l'effetto 'faro della polizia'.
Ma partiamo con la confezione: la scatola contiene solo la torcia, un cordino da attaccare alla torcia (se si desidera), e una custodia che sembra in tessuto per riporre la torcia, proteggendola da graffi e urti. NON vengono fornite batteria, quindi la torcia al suo arrivo, non è usabile, a meno che non si disponga già di batterie idonee. Viene fornito anche un piccolo manuale stampato, che fornisce indicazioni su come usarla, e quali batterie usare.
La torcia ha una forma cilindrica, con un diametro di circa 2,5 cm e una lunghezza di circa 14. Il peso è pari a circa 128 gr. per la sola torcia, che diventano 145 quando la torcia è inserita nella sua custodia. Sulla lato lungo, troviamo una clip per appendere la torcia, per esempio, alla cintura, e questa clip è abbastanza rigida. Accanto c'è un pulsante per variare la modalità di utilizzo, e sul fondo, dal lato opposto rispetto al led principale, troviamo l'interruttore di accensione principale. Il bordo laterale, è lavorato in modo da rendere la torcia gradevole, ma anche per permetterne una presa sicura, alternando parti più strette a parti più spesse, e lavorazioni 'a rete' e 'a righe'. La custodia è leggera, si chiude con del velcro, ossia quel materiale che mia nonna chiamava 'strap', e sul retro ha un anello per far passare una cinghia.
La torcia può essere alimentata con una pila 18650 o due CR123A: entrambi i formati sono insoliti, e difficilmente li avrete a casa, se non siete appassionati di elettronica, o possedete altri apparecchi che usano quel tipo di batterie. Il manuale consiglia di usare solo batterie Fenix ricaricabili, ma io uso delle normali batterie 18650 ricaricabili che ho a casa, e che uso con un'altra torcia, e non ho avuto finora alcun problema.
Quando viene accesa, la luce presenta una parte centrale tonda molto luminosa, e attorno una zona con luce meno intensa, larga circa 6 volte quella centrale.
Il fascio di luce, poi, non si attenua in pochi metri, ma permette di illuminare 'a giorno', anche zone distanti qualche decina di metri. Tanto per fare un esempio, l'ho provata in terrazzo, e riesco a illuminare benissimo il parcheggio dall'altra parte della strada, quando la luminosità è al massimo
La torcia arriva impostata in modalità 'tattica', ossia premendo il pulsante posteriore, si accende sempre alla massima potenza, e premendo ancora il pulsante, passeremo prima alla modalità lampeggio veloce, e poi alla modalità con luce a bassa intensità. Usando il pulsante piccolo sul lato, è possibile cambiare modalità, usando più livelli di luminosità. Per ora non ho sentito il bisogno di cambiare modalità, perché alla fine le modalità che mi servono sono 'luce al massimo' quando sono all'aperto, e 'luce al minimo' quando sono in casa.
Le torce Fenix PD3x che ho posseduto, hanno sempre avuto una vita media di 2-3 anni, perché con gli scossoni e gli spostamenti tipici dell'uso che si fa di questi prodotti, il rischio di danneggiamento è molto alto. D'altra parte, ho acquistato anche prodotti di marche più blasonate (tipo maglite), e con lo stesso uso, sono durate anche meno, quindi la resistenza di queste Fenix è decisamente buona.
Io ne ho una sempre in auto, per le emergenze (tipo foratura di sera, necessità di farmi vedere in caso di panne, o autodifesa), e ne ho regalata una a un familiare, che la usa quando esce di sera. Ho acquistato la PD35 da poco, quindi non me esprimo sulla durata nel tempo, ma viste le versioni precedenti, non posso che consigliare questo prodotto a tutti: automobilisti, campeggiatori, proprietari di animali che bisogna portare fuori anche di sera, etc.
Se cercate una torcia compatta ma molto, molto potente, solida ma leggera ' beh, dubito trovarete molte valide alternative.

review_title: フラッシュライトの完成形
reviews:
PD35ノーマルタイプよりも進化しています。明るさは1000ルーメンに上がり、サイドスイッチはゴムから金属製に変更となっています。金属製の方が耐久性に優れ、押した感触も私は好きです。また、通常のアウトドアモードの他にタクティカルモードにすることも可能で、サイドスイッチを長押しすることで切り替えることが可能です。
とにかく細部までつくりが良く、例えばテールキャップを外したネジの部分まで、ハードアノダイズド処理（傷が付き難い表面処理）がされています。他のレビューや口コミから高品質であることは予想しておりましたが、確かに細部のつくりや接点の金具・スプリング等をみても品質が高いことが確認できます。
更に、外箱は大変綺麗で、日本語の説明書が付属しており、5年保証が付いていますので安心です。
明るさは5段階に切り替えることが可能で、照明をOFF後も直前の明るさを記憶しており便利です。
高機能で、つくりが良く、耐久性も優れる現在のフラシュライトの集大成なるものだと感じます。
自身をもってお薦め出来る商品です。
従来は、日本のジェントスを多数使用しましたが、故障が多く信頼性が劣ります。
フラッシュライトの分野では、日本は中国に大きく先を越されていると感じます。

review_title: Eine Fenix.. Als Polizist die perfekte Privatanschaffung
reviews:
Zuerst sollte man wissen, was die Fenix für Funktionen hat.
Wenn einem bewusst wird, dass man zwei Funktionen hat die über einen und die verschiedenen Stufen über einen 2. Knopf gesteuert werden UND man diese dann kauft, sollte man sich darüber nicht beschweren.

Fenix hat hier nun wieder eine fantastische Taschenlampe gebaut, die für meinen täglichen Polizeidienst (LaPo Berlin) einwandfreie Arbeit leistet.

"Taktisch" klingt immer sehr wichtig.
Wirklich wichtig ist für mich, die verschiedenen Lichtstufen gut nutzen zu können. Dies klappt perfekt und bei der ersten Anwendung ohne Übung.

Durch den stabilen Aufbau mache ich mir wenig Sorgen, dass sie mir schnell kaputt geht und Regen war bisher auch kein Problem.

Ich kann sie somit nur weiter empfehlen.

review_title: I have a bunch of lights. This is definately #1
reviews:
Ok guys here's the review. I am a bit of a flashlight snob and I have a large supply of flashlights. I work in an industry where my flashlight is turned on and off in use 75+ times a day. I have had this light about 8 months. I have lights that cost in the $200 range for a rechargeable light, from coast, stream light, mag light, sure fire and the list goes on. This is hands down the best light I have ever owned and I put them through their paces. From being run over, to dropped from 7 ft to being used as a hammer to get something to act up or just move. I use my lights and admit I abuse them. my job is to get it done and get it done fast. I additionally carry this light for personal defense and carry a hefty firearm at all times concealed. This is my" go to" to know what goes bump in the night or just the dark places. It is super brite, super lite, powerful, long winded
(with good batteries), rugged, clip works well and positioned correctly for carry, in or outside of your pocket. At $150 I would gladly purchase this light again If I had to. $70 for this light, this is a smoking good light and I give it 6 stars out of 5.Im not paid to say this or brag. I'm just an ordinary guy that won't hesitate to tell ya that it's a POS when it is. But this light is 100% money well spent. Be sure to pick up extra batteries too. Ill take the pepsi challenge with any light on the market in the long haul against the pd35tac. Period. Because I have put it to the test.

review_title: bequem in der tasche, blendend hell
reviews:
wollte eig nur ne gute lampe für den tödlichen treppenabstieg, meines vaters häuschens und hab mir dann mal so n strobo gegönnt.
anfangs war ich enttäuscht, da man sich an das durchschalten gewöhnen muss und es einfach zu viele modie sind, aber im richtigen modus kommt man bei leichtem antippen durch: 100%, strob, dann 50% und durchdrücken fixiert die entsprechende einstellung dauerhaft. nach 3 maligem ärgern der kollegen hat man es unter kontrolle.
das strob, oder 100% irritieren selbst bei tageslicht im dunkeln bzw. bei offenen pupillen ist das teil besser als jedes P.-spray und nachdem das "weichziel" nichts mehr sieht, gibt's mit der lampe n andenken auf den schädel.
hab viel erwartet und wurde dennoch positiv überrascht. mal sehen, ob die guten akkus wirlklich noch mehr rausholen, denn dann ist das ding regelrecht gefährlich.

review_title: デザイン、質感共に最強の中華ライト
reviews:
[利点]
･明るい
･点灯モードに不足無し
･外装の加工品質が高い
[欠点]
･スイッチ部が出っ張っており、立てて置くことができない
･外観は良いが、ロゴ等の刻印が甘い

素晴らしいです。
あらゆる部分の作り込みが、ガジェット好きの心をくすぐります。
特にネジ部の精度は特筆すべきでしょう。
ボタン類のきっちりとした押し心地も素晴らしいの一言。

ただ、もう少し改善して欲しい事もあります。
まず、スイッチがケースの後端から飛び出ているため、ライトを垂直に立てておくことが出来ません。
照度が高く、リフレクターを付けるとランタン代わりになるのですが、立てて置けないのはつらいです。
あと、刻印のフォントが安っぽく、また、少しぼやけてます。
バージョンアップ時には是非改善していただきたいです。

review_title: Die Taschenlampe ist sehr hell - Für Blitzlicht müssen aber zwei Knöpfe gedrückt werden
reviews:
Die Taschenlampe ist klein, macht einen hochwertigen Eindruck und ist sehr hell.

Aus meiner Sicht negativ ist, dass es nicht möglich ist sofort das Blitzlicht zur Abschreckung einzusetzen. In einem Modus muss man sich durch die verschiedenen Lichtstufen durchklicken und somit ungeeignet. Im anderen Modus muss man einen separaten Schalter eine Sekunde betätigen. Auch nicht optimal, aber besser. Folgender Ablauf: Einschalten der Lampe, die Lampe leuchtet auf der höchsten Stufe und blendet sehr stark, Zweitens eine Sekunde auf den seitlichen Schalter drücken und die Lampe wechselt zum Blitzlicht.
product_name: Fenix Flashlights FX-PD35TAC Flashlight, 1000 Lumen, Black

#401 in Handheld Flashlights

reviews:
C'est ma troisième Fenix, j'ai eu deux PD35 classique, puis celle là. Mes deux PD35 précédentes m'ont lâché au bout de un an et demi toute les deux, rythme d'utilisation normal au quotidien.

Bon niveau garantie avec amazon pas de problème j'ai repayé aucune d'entre elles, le problème que j'ai sur celle-ci c'est que le bouton pour switch la puissance ne fonctionne pas. Je dois appuyer sur le bouton ON/OFF pour changer mes modes de luminosité et je n'en possède que deux, faible et puissant. J'ai essayé avec des piles neuves rien y fait.

Du-coup je laisse tomber Fenix et je me dirige vers Led lenser, leur torches sont plus grosse que les fenix mais la qualité est meiilleur et vous pouvez régler la largeur du faisceau pour éclairer loin ou près.

reviews:
Die Taschenlampe war ein Geschenk für meinen Vater. Er hatte sich diese Taschenlampe gewünscht und ist sehr zufrieden damit.

Schade ist allerdings das keine Batterien dabei sind. Vielleicht ist das üblich - ich hätte allerdings erwartet dass eine "einsatzfähige" Taschenlampe also inkl. Batterien geliefert wird oder dass in der Beschreibung ausdrücklich darauf hingewiesen wird dass es ohne Batterien ist - vor allem da Spezialbatterien benötigt werden die es nicht überall gibt.

Die Batterien/Akkus hat mein Vater dann extra gekauft - dazu musst er seinen Personalausweis eingeben und diese wurden nur an Ihn persönlich zugestellt. Scheinen also gefährlich zu sein :)

Zu den ganzen Funktionen kann ich nicht viel sagen aber sie ist auf jeden Fall extrem hell
Bei einigen anderen in der Familie steht die Taschenlampe jetzt auch auf der Wunschliste...

reviews:
für meine Zwecke. Vor dem kauf habe ich mich gründlich über die neuen LED Taschenlampen informiert. Kein Vergleich zu den Funzeln die wir als Kinder / Jugendliche hatten. Die Fenix ist sehr hell, kompakt und leicht. Ich betreibe die Lampe mit guten 18650er Akkus. Dadurch hält die Lampe ausgesprochen lange ihre Leistung. Es gibt weder Störungen bei Dauerregen noch bei Betrieb in Dreck, Sand oder Kälte. Alles ist gut abgedichtet. Durch das schnelle Wechseln der Modi hat man immer das perfekte Setup parat. Die Bedienung geht sehr schnell in Fleisch und Blut über.
Egal ob schnell mal ne Runde mit den Hunden im Regen durch den Park oder eine ausgedehnte Tour durch den Wald oder am Rhein entlang.. die Uhrzeit ist egal, wenn du diese Taschenlampe dabei hast. Sehr heller Spot mit schön abgegrenztem, ausreichend hellem Spill. Super abgestufte Leuchtstufen und wirklich krasser Strobe.
Ich liebe diese Taschenlampe und kann sie jedem empfehlen!
Klarer Kauftipp!

reviews: Die Lampe hat eine überragende Leuchtleistung und eine angenehme Größe. Der am Ende angebrachte Knopf für den Taktik-Modus ist sehr praktisch. Wäre er gegenüber dem Gehäuse etwas versenkt, so könnte man die Lampe hinstellen. So leider nicht möglich. Ein weiterer Kritikpunkt ist die extreme Hitzeentwicklung im hellsten Modus. Die Lampe wird so heiß, dass man sie nicht mehr anfassen kann (schon bevor sie runterschaltet). Bei der Anwendung mit dem Akku Fenix ARB-L18-2600U gab es zwei, drei Mal einen „Wackler“, wo die Lampe kurz ausging, obwohl die Batterie korrekt eingesetzt und das Gehäuse fest verschlossen war.

reviews: Piccola. Robusta. Fatta bene. Leggera. Ottima per uso notturno in tiro operativo. Facile la regolazione della intensità che rimane impostata anche dopo aver spento la pila. Pulsante posteriore molto sensibile. Unica pecca,non credo che le 1000 lumen siano proprio così tante e fascio di luce un poco troppo piccolo. Comunque fino a 100 mt si vede bene. Costa molto di più (considerando la batteria al litio ed il necessario caricatore della stessa) di pile dello stesso tipo di marchio concorrente. Ma questa è la più piccola in commercio. La custodia invece ha il gancio di fissaggio troppo lungo x cinturoni tattici da 5 cm,e pertanto al momento della estrazione si muove tutto.

review_title: The operating modes are useful and the light output is staggering
reviews:
This torch is extremely impressive. I was surprised by how small it is, very pocketable even in its case and the construction is superb.
The operating modes are useful and the light output is staggering. It's a car headlight in something the size of a large marker pen! It's strobe mode is very useful in a defensive situation (I presume).
My one and only crticism, and I'm being very picky, is the lack of a focussing mode but this unit is so efficient on flood that everything in front of the user IS illuminated so why bother focussing?
You'll need a 18650 battery and a suitable charger but the torch is supplied with a non-rechargeable battery to get you going after purchase.
It also comes with a reasonable belt case.
Seriously recommended.

review_title: Once you go PD35TAC, you never back.
reviews:
Best & Brightest Flashlight for its size that I've ever owned. I carry it with me everywhere.
Rather than an intense beam focused on a small limited area, the PD35TAC flashlight illuminates a larger, much wider area without sacrificing the intensity needed to "light up" the central direction of focus.
I own over 20 flashlights of varying sizes, makes & models, lumens, and specialties. The PD35TAC has quickly become my one and only "go to" flashlight for all my needs.
I work outdoors in a secured trucking yard at a warehouse. I use this light to see EVERYTHING I need to see; from right up close, to far off distances. (Our yard accommodates over 350 semi trailers, including 140 warehouse dock doors - to give an idea of how large an area it is.)
I also use the PD35TAC flashlight every morning & night when I walk my dog. We live in a rural area with plenty of forest all around us. Much wildlife inhabits these woods, including coyote and bear. I NEVER walk my dog in the dark without a flashlight, and since I purchased the PD35TAC, IT IS THE FLASHLIGHT I NEVER LEAVE HOME WITHOUT.

reviews:
This is the second Pd35 Fenix light i have owned. The first one lasted 6 months and i started having all kinds of issues to numerous to get into. I thought i may have had bad luck and i really liked it when it worked, so i purchased a second one through Amazon. As soon as i opened the box and turned it on, ive had nothing but intermittent on and off issues as well as brightness control settings problems. Im very familiar with this light and used reccomended batteries necessary for it to operate properly. I am not the only one to experience these kinds of issues with this particular unit according to other reviews. I can honestly say when it works properly its an awesome light.

According to the company website and other videos, there are adjustments you can do in order for it to work properly. After trying everything and still no luck i decided to just return the item. After all, should i have to repair or tweek a brand new item from the box in order for it to work properly. I would hope not. I think this in an engineering problem that could be addressed. Even though i love the light and the brand, i just cant justify spending nearly seventy dollars on something so unreliable and labeled as Tactical. Does the rest of the product line have these issues? At this hight of a price point im not willing to bet on it. Btw, this is my first return of an item on Amazon and first negative review. Buyer beware!
product_name: Fenix Flashlights FX-PD35TAC Flashlight, 1000 Lumen, Black
rank:

review_title: High light output. Typical Fenix high quality. Combine with good batteries and charger--see below for proven recommendations:
reviews:
Typical Fenix high quality. Have purchased several of different models; my favorite is the PD-35 series--have bought four over several years. This latest is the highest output, and significantly, features a superior LED. Unlike the previous (2014?) model which had a conspicuous yellow halo around the light beam striking an object, the 2015 has a clean beam of all one color temperature--I'd guess somewhere between 4000 and 5000 Kelvin. Just make sure you purchase with superior batteries and a charger, both available on Amazon:
Orbtronic 3200 mAhr 18650 protected lithium ion rechargeable (yes, they're worth the $$ in reduced fire hazard and increased life)
https://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B00CAD6AUE/ref=cm_cr_ryp_prd_ttl_sol_25
Nitecore D4 controlled charger
http://www.amazon.com/Nitecore-Integrated-Displays-Rechargeable-Batteries/dp/B00L1XYX4Y/ref=sr_1_5?ie=UTF8&qid=1452385745&sr=8-5&keywords=nitecore+d4

review_title: One of the best flashlights I've owned
reviews:
Without a doubt this Fenix PD35 "Tactical Edition" is one of the best flashlights I have owned. Compact and lightweight yet robust enough for the outdoors. Crafted from aircraft grade aluminum it appears to be able to take quite a lot of abuse. The Cree XP-L LED is powered by either a single 18650 Li-ion battery or 2ea. CR123 batteries and delivers up to 1000 Lumens. with a lifespan of 50,000 hrs. It has thermal and polarity regulation and is IPX 8 waterproof.
There are two modes of operation - Tactical Mode and Outdoor Mode - 6 brightness levels including strobe.
1. 8 Lumens 140 Hrs.
2. 60 Lumens - 29 Hrs approx.
3. 200 Lumens - 8 Hrs. 30 Mins.
4. 500 Lumens - 3 Hrs.
5. 1000 Lumens (Turbo) - 1 Hr.
The beam will reach out to approx. 600 FT.
Size = 5.4" long x 1.0" Diameter.
Weight is 3.1 oz. excluding the battery.
My only complaint is the case that comes with the light, I think Fenix could have done a better job.
I purchased a different case and here is the link to that one .... https://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B00XABFMVI/ref=oh_aui_detailpage_o00_s01?ie=UTF8&psc=1
I'm very satisfied with this purchase and highly recommend this flashlight.

review_title: Light weight reliable light but NO tail stand
reviews:
Love the light but for two things. Everything else is ideal. Size, weight, brightness and switch functions.
1. The holster provided will not hold this light, it is too tight. No one should need a third hand just to put their flashlight in the holster.
2. The should be able to stand on its tail but it does not. So if you need to here are possible solutions for you.
a. old old old film container
b. coin collector quarter stack container
c. sugar test strip container
I have all of these and tried them and they work well. Tip if you use the quarter storage container put 4 to 6quarters in bottom and it really stabilizes with the weight.
That said it is a good flashlight. Every person has different priorities and money they will spend. If you don't need a holster or you intend to buy a better separate one then you are golden. Tail standing can be over come.

review_title: Batteries are NOT included with weaponized flashlight
reviews:
Weaponized flashlight. Confusions are instructing. Best set to mid power output for general use. You can use the side button to trigger strobe mode. Just hold it for three seconds. You've got the time. Then wham! 1000 lumens of very psychedelic strobe that will likely confuse anyone. Side switch turns that right off and puts you back to the previous illumination.

It could use a better heat sink. The light warms up fast. The end switch cap doesn't quit line up with the side switch. This makes pinky operation of the side switch more difficult, particularly with off hand. I presume you would want your strong hand available for chemical or kinetic energy weapon. Or perhaps just car keys if you haven't switched to proximity fobs yet. Momentary on is in your preset brightness rather than turbo mode, so you can't use that as a brief snap flash unless you are already set to turbo mode.

review_title: Best light I found for personal defense, reliability, technology,survival, and taking my 2 dogs out
reviews: This really is the best light I found for personal defense, reliability, technology,survival, and taking my 2 dogs out. Friends that were top tier operators trained me. I am not a top tier operations guy myself but been told I am better in tactical defense than over 90% of regular guys. I love the compact size, 6 output modes up to 1000 lumen light options (though in self defense situation Id keep it fast/simple, go for the the 1000 lumen, and hope I don't hit the side button unintentional unless I wanted the strobe mode), durability, reliability, size, performance, and technology. I am a high level engineer and appreciate especially the durability, reliability, size, performance, and technology. I usually take my 2 big dogs out one at a time and either have this compact great light in my hand or in my pocket handy. I am very aware of my surroundings by my sight and sound but my dogs are my long range radar especially at night. I never use my dogs as self defense, they most likely would be hurt or killed along with me if we were attacked. I am licensed to conceal carry a firearm, and I am very well trained to defend myself if my life was at risk. I have been taught methods in identification, escape and evasion of potential dangers . The other light modes are useful as utility. I bought two of these lights this year to have one handy when I needed it. Cheers.

reviews:
Hard to beat the lumens and candela/range of this, and splash/periphery is good. Super bright when you want, and beam is thrown hundreds of meters. I like the flexibility of 5 settings of lumens. Though keep in mind that high settings on this and some other flashlights burn batteries very quickly, so plan accordingly in how you use it, and/or stocking up on batteries.

Works well as a tactical light for low-light shooting drills- I wish this came in a weapon mounted version. Just keep in mind you should really practice a lot how to change the light settings if you’re going to in a tactical situation- or ideally leave it on one, lower setting if clearing a house. Lanyard is short and allows the light to be easily dropped if you switch to a weapon mounted light.

Dropped it accidentally at least once, and still works apart from mild scratches. Hard to beat the excellent waterproof rating. Just be aware of how hot the tip can get on high settings- especially if left standing on the tip, or too close to something else.

review_title: The best small light I’ve owned.
reviews:
Packaged well and comes with detailed instructions to access the modes. Seems sturdy.

Photos... I started by taking a photo with no light in my yard. ⅓ acre. Narrow and deep. Then I started with the lowest brightness and took photos of the five levels of brightness on outdoor mode. Outdoor mode lets you cycle through the 5 brightness settings by tapping the side button. I followed the same steps with my cars. No light, then 5 levels of brightness.

Note: the 4th and 5th levels look the same in the photos, but Turbo mode(brightest) is noticeably brighter than the next setting down. I’m also pleasantly surprised with the throw and beam. Makes me forget that it can’t zoom. This light also stays put in my breast pocket of my work shirt using the clip that comes on it.

I put this light to the test by running it in turbo mode for at least 5 minutes. It eventually got hot, but you can still hold it. I kept it in the middle brightness setting for about an hour with no issues. I was changing the oil on my cars. Worked great. It was dark out, so it came in handy when I was filling the oil after draining. I used a fully charged 18650 battery.

There are more detailed instructions included than I will review in the next two paragraphs.

Tactical mode: this mode allows you to simply turn the light on and off with the tail button. It defaults to turbo mode (1,000 lumens). It’s super bright, and seems to be a legit rating. Remember that lumens eating is each diode, not overall output of combined diodes, so appearance may vary from various lights. This light has only one diode, yet is shockingly bright. Strobe setting in either mode will easily blind anyone looking at it.

Outdoor mode lets you turn the light on and off with a click of the tail button. The side button changes brightness with each tap, scaling up in brightness as you tap. It goes in this order... eco(8), low(60), mid(200) high(500), turbo(1,000).

The holster fits, and I will use it when I’m not wearing a shirt with pockets.

Pros:
Looks great

Tactical and outdoor modes are both useful.

Uses a 18650 battery(just be careful in cold weather)

Both modes are easy to use, once you read the instructions.

Eco is great for navigating the house at night.

Turbo is incredibly bright and effective.

Beam width and throw are so good, you’ll forget you can’t zoom it.

Seems to be a good value.

Cons:

Cannot tail stand (fine by me, but worth noting)

reviews:
I can’t recommend this light anymore. First off the light is faulty. I’ve had mine for about 2 years. Rarely used it until switching to night shift a few months ago and even then I only use it for short periods of time a few nights a week. I’ve had to replace the battery 3 times in 4 months. This thing drains batteries so fast. I don’t even use it on the highest brightness. Which on that topic, my light gets very hot on the highest level. Not sure if mine is defective or what. Again, it’s barely gotten any use.

Second issue is these guys have really slow/poor customer service. I've left them 2 voice messages in 2 weeks and not yet received a return call. Their chat feature is always off line too. This isn't because of Covid either. I had another Fenix Lighting product I had to contact them about maybe 4 years ago now and it was the same dance. I'd leave messages and it took them WEEKS to get back to me. That's pretty unacceptable. Highly doubt I'll purchase another Fenix light after this.

reviews: The flashlight is awesome. Super bright, long lasting, durable construction. Fits in my pocket easily for EDC. It throws a decent length, maybe 200m at 1,000 lumen, but is more of a floodlight with a nice balance of throw/flood considering it’s not zoomable. Be advised however, this is for the flashlight only, battery (and battery charger) not included. I ended up returning my amazon purchase because it wasn’t clear the battery didn’t come with (even amazon thinks battery is included based on the lithium battery hazmat stickers that it shipped with), but while browsing Fenix’s website to see what battery to buy I saw that first time fenix buyers get 20% off their order and with flashlight, battery and charger it came out cheaper to buy direct from them (free 3-day). If you are buying from amazon, the flashlight can accommodate a 3500mAh 18650 battery, Nitecore makes a good one. 5 star flashlight, 3 star unclear advertising

review_title: A miniature Sun in the palm of your hand.
reviews:
This is a flashlight. No, more like a miniature Sun in your hand. The turbo mode with a fully charged battery is blinding, I can light up my entire room like daytime with this lovely device at night.

I very much appreciate the strobe mode, very good for self-defense as whoever is attacking will not be able to see or identify you and will disorient them. I had my brother strobe me to see the effect, good luck being able to see or think clearly for a while haha.

Completely worth the money I payed for it, I was skeptical as the most expensive flashlight I purchased before this was $10 and was okay, I figured at about 6 times the price, I would get at least 6 times the luminosity. Oh boy was I mistaken, I got closer to 100 times more light. 1,000 lumens is no joke, holding the light near your skin on turbo mode will begin to get hot and burn, gotta love a powerful tool.

I chose this one for the tactical features and carry clip, I love the carry clip, which also rotates 360 degrees. The build quality is outstanding, nothing about this looks or feels cheap. I will only buy these flashlights from now on, expensive, but if you need a real bada$$ flashlight that is concealable and tactical, this is the one.

review_title: Almost perfect. Great bang for the buck
reviews:
PROS:

*Light works perfectly
*Durable construction
*Very lightweight and compact for a light that is this bright
*Flood pattern is great for walking the dog when it's pitch black outside

CONS:
*CANNOT tailstand!!! There are so many instances when camping where I would like to set the light down, but there is no way to tailstand it.
*The throw isn't as far as other lights as this leans more towards a flood light pattern
*The low (8 lumens) is too high. For a light this size, they should've went with 3 or 5 lumen for low (for map reading) and to extend battery life. I often find myself in situations (passenger in a dark car) where I need a light to search for something in my bag. Although 8 lumen is "OK", I would prefer it to be lowered to around 3 lumen so it doesn't take my night vision as long to recover.

I liked the light so much that I immediately bought another one to replace it and knowing that Fenix had a warranty I sent their customer service an email and told them that I dropped it and broke it. They asked if the head or the switch was the defective part to which I told them the head and they immediately volunteered to send me a replacement head.

Today I have received the replacement head and now have a complete backup incase I manage to break another one. I own multiple high-end weapon lights and this light holds its own.

review_title: The PD35 works great and is reliable.
reviews: This has been a great flashlight. Although I lost it I will be getting another one. I used this flashlight at work and I have never had a problem with the light. The flashlight has several power settings to cycle through to for the desired brightness. It also will dim to a lower lumen setting when the battery charge is getting low. I have gotten hours of use of bright light (not using at full power) off of a single charged battery. This flashlight is waterproof and has a good seal to prevent moister from getting on the inside, The head of the flashlight housing can get hot when used on the highest setting for a prolonged period of time. The throw distance is great and the strobe feature works effectively. The flashlight fits comfortably in the hand with offering any bulk and will fit comfortably in the pocket if you decide not to wear the pouch. I would not recommend wearing it in a shirt pocket as it would add too much weight.

This a spotlight masquerading as a flashlight. It is incredibly bright and definitely capable of projecting its light an incredibly far distance. I do not use it at its brightest setting, but it is nice to know you have it available. I would say this is definitely a luxury buy, as the light is definitely overkill for home use unless you live on an acre, or more, of property where animal visitors frequently like to visit. As always, your battery life will depend on frequency of use and your preferred brightness. On the scale of portable nightlight (1) to helicopter spotlight (5), I have it on 2 or 3 most of the time, which yields a longer battery life without sacrificing visibility. It a a quality torch.

The controls are a bit strange, as the power is on the tail, but is also used to switch to strobe. The button on the side is used to adjust brightness, but it takes less than a few minutes to read the instructions and master the flashlight.

reviews: This is the third Fenix (PD35) we've purchased. Why do we need so many flashlights? I'll get to that in a minute. Purchased my first Fenix (PD35) about 5 years ago. This poor thing has survived being dropped on the trail, falling off the bike multiple times (Fenix, PD35 universal bike mounts sucks, fyi, sorry) and being run over by god knows how many cars ie. (one night after a bike ride I placed my PD35 and my rechargeable brake light on the side of my truck bed, drove off and lost 'em. Came back and found them in the middle of an intersection, the brake light was toast (FUBAR) crushed beyond recognition. Obviously it had been run over.) The PD35? Had some scrapes and a couple of nicks but it still works just fine. Seriously, 5 years old, or thereabout and even the Fenix battery still works. The PD35 does get a bit hot when in use for a long time, I was worried about this when it was new, thinking it was going to melt or fry out or something but after 5 years Im no longer concerned. Also, I live in the desert, its hot here, I wonder if this light gets as hot in cooler climates. Anyway, the first PD35 is now my bike light, the second is my handheld for working around the house, hiking, night walking, camping ect. The third is now the light for the second bike. Love this thing! 10/10 would buy again.

review_title: Great pocket sized tactlight, but get ready to spend some money.
reviews: This is one of the best flashlights I've ever own. It is very bright, has different brightness and flash settings, and seems to be well made. It's a bit pricey though, but if you're looking for a tactlight that's made to last you will definitely have to spend some money. The cheaper tactlights sold online won't last long under regular use. Only downfall on this tactlight is that the head gets a bit hot after long use on the high beam setting. So make sure not to leave the tactlight on for too long, or leave it near flammable items while the tactlight has been in use for a long time to prevent a fire.

reviews: I've always wanted a compact, "tactical," high-lumen flashlight that didn't break the bank. I did a lot of research and this one was it. I keep it set on level 2 and that's plenty of light to see most everything nearby very clearly. But then crank it up to level 5 and you can spot a gnat 100 yards away! I joke, but on high this thing is very bright and you can see quite a distance. And the strobe mode is absolutely blinding. Quality build, buttons feels solid, nothing seems cheap about it. I bought extra batteries but I've played around with his thing for hours and am still on the first battery. I camp and fish a lot, and this is now a staple in my back pack. Don't try to hide from me at night, cuz now I can see you!

reviews: With the right batteries this is a extremely good flashlight. You can adjust the output / brightness from low which gives minimal illumination, think a standard flashlight which is about to fail, to about the intensity of a triple "D" battery maglite with fresh alkaline batteries. The only thing it lacks is a focused long throw beam. I just happen to really like the long throw beam aspect of the mini maglite which is the only reason for the four stars as this flashlight is superior in every other respect as it should be for the price. You should add the red filter by Fenix to your order... with its intensity and a red filter you'd be amazed at how useful this flash is at night. You don't need to press the filter on fully as it is not a perfect fit. The red filter makes the full intensity less notable and glaring from close to medium ranges and when you turn it off your eyes will barely notice the change.

review_title: Brightest pocket flashlight I've ever owned!
reviews: I've had this for over a year and a half and it's spectacular! I use it when hiking and riding a bike. I've dropped it a few times on concrete and blacktop and it still works great. My friends are always blown away by the brightness. This will illuminate the side of a hill on a pitch black night. The high setting can make it very hot. It burned a hole through the holster when it was turned on by accident while in my bag. There should be a safety that prevents it from automatically turning on when button is depressed while the light is in a bag or pocket. Luckily it didn't start a fire. The strobe is blinding and can be used for defensive actions. The CR123 batteries work well, but can be expensive unless purchased in bulk. The batteries last awhile, but can lose their juice if you're only using the highest setting. I'd definitely buy it again and recommend this light to others.

reviews: Although this is the first "tactical" flashlight I have owned, and therefore cannot compare it to others in that class, it is absolutely a tremendous flashlight. Beside it, the "headlamp" style flashlights I have been using are a joke -- the Fenix brightens an area at least four times deeper. Took it camping in the Allagash last week and absolutely illuminated the campsite from inside the tent. And, if used defensively, this flashlight is easily bright enough to blind an attacker. It has five different levels of brightness, along with a "strobe" mode, which blinks the light rapidly on and off at varying rates -- great for signaling or disorienting an attacker. The brightest level is daylight-bright, it's really amazing. The flashlight is powered by one rechargeable specialty battery, expensive but long-lived. The unit is solidly built of sturdy aluminum and has a real heft to it compared to the typical plastic-case lights. I have dropped it a couple of times without issue and I expect it will outlive me. This is in fact an expensive flashlight if all you need is something to keep in the drawer if the power goes out -- but if you really want to light up the night with a solidly-built defensive weapon (honestly, it's tough enough to use as a club although you'd do better it holding it away from an attacker and shining it in the eyes), I don't see how you can do better than this.

review_title: A robust tank at a fair price.
reviews: I own 4 Fenix flashlights, 3 handheld, 1 headlamp. They all work fantastically, they are very robust ( I work on a oil & gas drilling rig and have dropped them multiple times with no issues.) Infact I dropped a PD35 in a shaker bin ( large tub holds 4000 gallons fluid) that had oil based mud in it (diesel mixed with thicken agents to raise its overall weight per gallon). Basically it’s used motor oil. After 30 very tense minutes I was able to retrievie the light, it was fine, wiped it off, sprayed it down with pressure washer, all good. It was still shinning bright as ever! I’m not sure there is much more I need to say.

reviews:
I use this light every day as my go to edc light and for scanning the back yard when I let the dog out at night.

The lumens level is great, and I enjoy the variety of power settings. Even though I've used this every day for the last six months or so, I've only replaced the batteries once. Obviously I don't blast on high lumens unless I need it.

The light does a great job for what it does, lighting stuff up! In addition to the lumens settings you can also soft press the button to turn the flashlight on, great if you're looking to avoid a full press of the button or want to pop a quick flash of light out. Home defense people should like this feature, which can be hard to find on similar lights.

This Fenix model is a bit thick to be using as an edc in your pants pocket, so you might want to consider using the belt attachment that comes with it instead, or keep it in a coat pocket. It fits fine in my pants, but it does bulge a bit, unlike say a stream light pen light.

The one thing that stops me from giving this flashlight five stars is the issue I have getting it to work every time new batteries go in it. I'm not stupid, I know how battery direction works- but when I put new batteries in the flashlight it will refuse to turn on. I'll need to readjust them or put them in a couple of times until the connection gets completed, and then I don't have an issue. When I first got the light and struggled with this issue I thought it was defective and was planning on returning it, but after some tinkering with the batteries for five or so minutes I got it to work. The same issue occurred when I replaced the batteries months later. I used stream light batteries in the size needed, next time I'll try a different brand. Either way its either a connection issue battery to battery, or battery to light.

I'll update my review when I try new batteries, and if it is a battery brand issue I'll move the rating to five stars.

Overall, the Fenix FX-PD35 is a quality built light for a good price with great features. Expect to have this light on you for years.

.

What is the purpose of this flashlight, to have on for a few minutes or less? My worst purchase on Amazon by far and my family and businesses have purchased a ton on Amazon. review_title: Hands Down the Best in the Business
reviews:
I own two PD35-TAC's and two PD35's. This is hands down my go-to flashlight. I currently have a PD-35 TAC on my rifle and one on my belt. I swapped the TAC for the regular PD on my rifle and it's worked wonders. The other PD my wife carries. Is it worth switching up to the TAC vs the price? No, not really. The extra couple lumens you wont notice. But if you're just going into the PD series for the first time, go big or go home (go for the TAC).

How do these perform? I'd prefer a little more of a focused beam as this has a bit of flood. When mounted on my rifle (and I'll put up an image of it mounted later), I get a significant amount of the light showing the barrel of my rifle. But handheld, it's solid for clearing rooms, searching yards, etc.

Before the PD series I came from the Fenix TK-40. Which if you've ever held one, is a BEAST of a flashlight. No way near capable of being mounted, terrible in the hand (unless you wanted to club someone) and chews through AA's like a monster. Going to this light is ridiculous in comparison. Not to mention a bump of almost 800 lumens.

I'm a big fan of Fenix lights. I'll only buy them exclusively now. If I had to buy another one this very moment... I'd definitely get myself a PD35-TAC.

review_title: Great strong flashlight with a small but
reviews:
A bit pricy but a very good quality flashlight (cost me $110 including the li-ion batteries and a digital charger). We used this light in our recent holidays and lots of night photography sessions, I was really amazed with the quality and strength of the flash light when I was casting the light to a far away hill (only it causes blue hue in the atmosphere in between in the photos due to distance, but the hill has got exposed which was about 1 km away). The modes are very useful: I easily switched to lowest mode when I used it in tight spaces (such as looking for stuff in car boot), the strong mode would be blinding for that purpose. We did a fair bit of cave exploration, my partner tipped over at one of rocky waterlogged passages and submerged under water, she was worried the flashlight would get water in, we continued to submerge the flash afterwards for fun of it, I checked after coming out (and drying the outer housing) there was no sign of dampness inside, so it is really waterproof. It is excellent for outdoors, caving and camping.
However, I would like to share my experience with this light for photography use. I bought this light mainly for light painting and my night photography use. It is really strong and casts light to far away distance, but there is a little issue when you want to direct light for your target that I think you need to be aware of if you are also buying it for photography use. The light casts a strong central spot which is quite strong and lights up your far away subject, but it also casts I few stops dimmer light around that bright spot. This causes issues in long exposures: you can't control to expose only where you want, the area around your subject also will expose. I was trying to expose a tree at the beach without exposing the sand and passage going to the beach, but wasn't able to because the halo light made the sand also to appear in the photos. I still like this flashlight a lot, happy I bought it, and looking forward to use it more outdoors as well as photography. I will however, keep an eye for a flashlight that allows me to control the angle of light for specifically light painting.
