review_title: In My Opinion: Maybe For The 'Tactical' Types...
reviews:
In my opinion:

Have had and used this light off & on for a while now.

Never had a need for other than it's lowest two settings, and even then it's consumption of pricy 123A batteries seems high. It's nice knowing the higher modes are available, but in my case really never expect need for them; and especially never foresee need or use of the products embarrassing/gimmicky 'disco' (or however marketed) flash mode.

Light is also a little large to be carried clipped in jean front pockets... it can be done but is annoying. In normal use, the side selector button gets inadvertently pressed on occasion... invariably at inconvenient times. Said side button can be difficult/awkward to find by feel in the dark; notably when wearing gloves. The lights lack of 'tail stand' ability is another issue.

Product is beautifully constructed... CNC and anodize work is exquisite. Suspect it mostly consists of some variety of 6061. Light output is a bit on the cool side and displays no detectable PWM (Pulse Width Modulation) strobing.

This light probably meets needs of the 'tactical' crowd it's marketed to... and/or a source of mirth & merriment for 'tree spotter' types. However, for a technician who requires an unobtrusive easy to carry every day pocket light, I found it to be a 'useable', but suboptimal selection.

I purchased a second one of these lights as a gift for a colleague who initially showed interest in mine... however I suspect he later reached similar conclusions as I seldom see him with it anymore.

Review posted 7/16/2017 and will be updated should experience warrant.

Again, just my opinion.

***

review_title: Almost Perfect....just a couple personal nit picks.
reviews:
I would give this 4.5 stars. The light is well made, uses the Cree LED and has off, low, medium, high, turbo (timed), and strobe capabilities. There is a momentary ON/OFF by lightly depressing the tail switch. There is also a button type switch on the body that allows you to cycle through the lights. Holding it down activates the strobe function. Beam spread is great, with a very bright, defined center and a less intense, ambient light circle. I find this arrangement most useful.
Why did I deduct a star (should really just be 1/2 a star)? The light includes a Cordura belt case, extra O-rings, a lanyard and a pocket clip, but no battery. I need a battery, the other items are great, but not required to make the light work. Fenix documentation recommends their own 18650 battery, but makes it appear others should not be used. I would stay away from the counterfeit, cheap batteries, but Panasonic or the branded Panasonic's by Orbtronics 3400 Ah and a few others, are outstanding for use in these lights.
The light itself is excellent, and appears well made. I'm pleased there is a remote switch available for use on a tactical shotgun. I do not like the wire coil that may snag or having to tape up the excess wire. I know there are applications for this type cord, but I want the ability to customize the fit, so I don't have a possible hazard hanging off my weapon. Moving with the muzzle pointed down, then raising the weapon at a target, and getting the wire caught on dresser or cabinet knob is a real possibility I prefer to avoid. These are nits, and personal taste. The light itself is excellent and I would highly recommend them.

review_title: Great construction, great durability and BRIGHT (good for self defense)
reviews: Fenix makes great products -- this flashlight is no exception -- our 5th one -- gave one away, keep one in each of two vehicles and one in the house (and for travel) and one mounted on my rifle. Their construction is outstanding, the slim size plus 1000 lumens of brightness on high setting makes a great self defense tool -- when traveling, I carry one in my shirt pocket -- shine that in somebody's eyes at night and they will not see anything for several minutes. The lithium batteries have long life just sitting unused in the Fenix flashlights in our vehicles -- whereas previous flashlights could not be depended on after months to still have any battery life. In this case, I felt that I got what I paid for.

review_title: Extremely bright when needed yet adjustable for other uses.
reviews: I carry this flashlight with me every day. My original intent was for personal protection because it is VERY bright on it's highest setting and it would absolutely blind anyone you point it at. But I've found that with my aging eyes and the need for more light on the subject that I have used this flashlight almost every day more as a normal light and usually use the button on the side to dim the light to a reasonable level to do what I need to do. It stays at the level last used which is usually good for me but if I needed or wanted the highest setting I would then have to cycle the side button until I got to the setting I wanted. And at the highest setting it gets hot really fast so unless you needed to blind someone then you will most likely dim it down for normal use. I will note that it won't stand on it's tail as the push button on the back end protrudes far enough to prevent that but the flats on the bezel will allow you to lean it against something like a cabinet wall if working hands free. It's very compact especially for how bright it is and is easily carried on the belt. The case is rather flimsy but does it's job and I will most likely replace it someday with a heavier case. All in all, this light is very good for personal defense and extremely good for everyday use around the house.

review_title: Why did I shine this stupid thing in my eye?
reviews:
I've been getting PD-series Fenix lights every few years. Their performance has grown exponentially and is comparable to Surefire at easily half the price.

These lights are tough, light, compact, and powerful. Not sure if it's a true 1000-lumen but it really doesn't matter because unless you're using it as a substitute for headlights while driving at highway speeds on a cloudy night a hundred miles from the nearest town, you're not going to have a problem seeing ahead of you. By the way, pictures of this light's performance at night don't do it any justice. I've used it to light up treetops 200 yards away, and of course made the mistake of shining it into my retina to check its tactical capacity. I figure it's strong enough to blind/disorient and ruin your night vision at 40 feet +, so it's definitely rifle-ready. There are stronger lights out there but for the price, it's the way to go.

The belt holster for this model is not as good as it was a few years ago, the light doesn't sit deep enough in it, so you may need a custom fit. Same thing with the belt clip - sticks out of the pocket too far in my opinion. If you want to never think about your battery life, set to medium and run it off the Panasonic 3400mah Japanese made 18650s (the green ones), best battery for the $ at the time of this writing. Happy to answer questions.

reviews: Awesome flashlight at an amazing price point! I am a law enforcement officer and a firearms instructor so I'm always sniffing around and looking for great tactical lights. I own a Streamlight and a Surefire and I think this Fenix product is on par with both of them at a much better price. The construction is solid and durable, the clip is sturdy and useful, and the tail switch is responsive and has a nice durable feel to it. The size and weight are phenomenal, the diameter is perfect for fitting in the hand while shooting at night. The beam is holy crap bright and has a good general purpose focus, some people don' like that the focus is not adjustable but I actually do, I don't want to risk turning it on and having it way to dispersed when I meant to have it tight. The outdoor mode is great because you can switch between brightness settings almost instantly. I will have it set to 500 lumens for some shooting and then I can switch it to a lower setting while examining targets and reloading so I don't burn through the ridiculously expensive batteries. I don't know what else to say, I might just buy another one before somebody realizes this is priced too cheaply...

reviews:
After almost a year of carrying and using this flashlight, I still love it. I'm a bit of a flashlight junkie and have owned and used dozens of flashlights over the years, and this one is at the top of the pile.

It's sturdy, bright (almost too bright!), and light enough to not even notice on your belt, clipped into a pocket, or carried in a pack.

I purchased this light with the 3400 mAh Orbtronic batteries. Although I have yet to actually time the lifespan in all its modes, it absolutely maintains its light output all the way down to a dead battery. That being said, and noting that I rarely ever use this flashlight on max output (low or medium usually provides enough light for my purposed) I've found that the batteries will more than last for a work week without having to change the batteries (under moderate use).

Although at its price point it may be off-putting to some, keep in mind you're getting ten times the flashlight you're going to find at WalMart or the hardware store.

I'm thinking of buying a few more to keep in the car and in the house.

reviews:
This is a decent flashlight in the $60-70 range.

Someone said he/she would happily pay $150 for this light, that is ridiculous. I don't know why this person would say such a ridiculous thing, but it was said. I would suggest you disregard the review in question. In the range of $150 I'd buy an Elzetta. I don't want to spend that much on a flashlight though so I bought this.

My chief complaint is the tail cap. It's very easy to click, even when you don't mean to. At some point in my day I wonder why is my pocket so hot, then I remember the flashlight and take it out incredibly hot and turn it off. This happens at least once a day. I carry it in my left front pocket, because that's where I have space, and at some point during my day I bend over, or sit down and accidentally click the tail cap.

I bought this to be an ECD light, but it sucks for that. It will live out its life as my nightstand light. For ECD I'm going back to a light that uses a notary cap for constant on function.

For the money, and by that I mean no more than $70 this isn't a horrible light, it just isn't right for me.

reviews:
Great little flashlight, but it doesn't need 5 modes. This is certainly a minor nit, but it is difficult to see the difference between "High" and "Turbo" modes (500 and 1,000 lumens, respectively) and given the extra heat buildup and reduced battery life of the Turbo mode, I never use it. The "Eco" mode (8 lumens) is not really useful except perhaps in a true survival situation (runtime: 140hours). I would have been happy with three modes, Low, Medium and High.

Construction seems excellent, well finished and is a joy to hold in the hand. On/Off switch has a nice positive (waterproof) feel with a momentary function, the mode switch seems a little less positive, but I don't use the mode switch often. I purchased the ARC-1 charger and two ARB-L2 batteries (18650, 3200mAh) to go with this light from the Fenix web site. They also carry a flashlight mount to fix the light to a Picatinny/Weaver rail system and a remote On/Off switch.
